title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes the first criterion below, but not the second.
The response accurately inlcudes both of the criteria below.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

A response that states “an expansionary fiscal policy and an expansionary monetary policy” rather than providing examples of expansionary fiscal and monetary policy actions is not an acceptable response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes one of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the monetary policy action identified in part (b).
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes the first criterion below but not the second.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the change in the policy rate shown in part (c).

The response must both state that aggregate demand will increase and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that aggregate demand will increase and/or does not explain that a decrease in the policy rate will increase interest-sensitive consumption and/or investment spending.
The response states that aggregate demand will increase and explains that a decrease in the policy rate will increase interest-sensitive consumption and/or investment spending.

title: Part (e)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the change in aggregate demand in the short run identified in part (d).
descriptions: The response does not show point Z anywhere to the left of point X on the SRPC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaae4uaiaabkfacaqGqbGaae4qaaaa@3939@ (see below).

The response shows point Z anywhere to the left of point X on the SRPC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaae4uaiaabkfacaqGqbGaae4qaaaa@3939@ (see below).

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left in the long run and/or does not explain that nominal wages, input prices, and/or inflationary expectations will decrease in the long run.

The response states that the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left in the long run and explains that nominal wages, input prices, and/or inflationary expectations will decrease in the long run.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state a supply-side fiscal policy that would promote economic growth, such as

· Increasing spending on education

· Increasing spending on research and development

· Increasing spending on infrastructure and physical capital

· Increasing spending on training to improve labor productivity

· Reducing business income taxes

The response states a supply-side fiscal policy that would promote economic growth, such as

· Increasing spending on education

· Increasing spending on research and development

· Increasing spending on infrastructure and physical capital

· Increasing spending on training to improve labor productivity

· Reducing business income taxes
